turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What have you done about Irving August?

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Oh, I'm making investigations.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You've never believed a word I told you about Mr. August.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Look, Mary, now that I know you better, I think I can be more frank with you. I don't believe you. I still can't understand the reason for such a wild tale. It's like some of Jacqueline's stories.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Greg, it isn't a wild tale. It's true. If there were only some way --

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: There is a very simple way. Got a telephone book?

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Please - I can't explain things like this to your right ear.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Last night in this very restaurant Mr. Jason Hoag paid a very pretty compliment to my right ear.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Who the devil is he?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: A poet. He's sitting right over there. That's his table  the one at the feet of Dante.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You could have told me any time you were Jacqueline's husband.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Things changed, Mary. The reasons for finding Jacqueline changed. I want to find Jacqueline to settle things.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What things? Why?

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: She's got to be found. That's the first step. She's got to be found so that she can give herself up to the police.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We've tried so long to find her.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't. We know what happened. Don't go on.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Any court in the land would understand. We'll wait a few days -- let you rest -- then we'll go to the police.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It will all be over in such a little while, Jacqueline, and everything will be all right again. Drink your coffee.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: I thought I might close up the apartment -- maybe get a place in Connecticut.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You'd love that, Jackie. Remember that last summer with Mother in the Berkshires? You used to help the gardener.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Good night, Jacqueline -- good night, Mary.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: That was Dr. Judd. He was phoning to say that, Jacqueline is on her way here -

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Gregory   you'd better take Jacqueline with you tonight.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: It's what I should have done yesterday. I'll take her away somewhere where she can rest.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: No. Stay that way. I want to talk to you. I love you - you know that?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Perhaps, later, when things are settled, when Jacqueline's well again -- maybe we can arrange things differently.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I've never loved any one before, Gregory, and I do love you - you must know it -- but Jacqueline's my sister  whom I had lost and have found again....

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: I know  I shouldn't have told you

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, I'm glad....at least I've heard you say it...

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I'm going to find your sister.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: I don't think that's a good subject for jokes, Mr. Hoag.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: But I'm not joking.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Don't be ridiculous. For months I've had the best private detective in New York looking for Miss Gibson.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: But I'm better than a detective. I have an understanding of people - and a love of them -- an understanding of the city - -

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: You don't even know Jacqueline Gibson.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: But I understand her. That may be more important.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: It may make very fine poetry, Mr. Hoag, but it doesn't make good sense.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Mary, when you first came here, I told you to look into your heart. You didn't listen to me. You listened to the policeman instead. You didn't find your sister, did you?

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Look here, just because Mrs. Romari asked you to amuse us.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: This is the part of New York I love. It is old. It has memories. If you listen, the houses will speak to you. Walt Whitman...Edna St. Vincent Millay... Eugene O'Neill...in their time they've all lived here.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: All very nice but, what are you going to do - listen at every house in New York for Jacqueline's voice?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I'm looking for a party -- a merry party.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Well, that's illuminating.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Do you think he knows about this?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: He's clever and he's cautious in his way. If he knew I think he'd advise her to do what I want - surrender herself to the police  stand trial  I don't think he knows.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: We could tell him.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Could you find him?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I suppose so. I can pick him up somewhere.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Verse -- verse that I wrote. I need it.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Let her know what?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: That you love Mary.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: She'll have to know some time.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Not from me.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: MIMI
turns.text: I'm Mimi -- I'm dying.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: MIMI
turns.text: Yes. It's been quiet, oh ever so quiet. I hardly move, yet it keeps coming all the time -closer and closer. I rest and rest and yet I am dying.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: And you don't want to die. I've always wanted to die -- always.

turns.speaker: MIMI
turns.text: I'm afraid.

turns.speaker: MIMI
turns.text: I'm tired of being afraid - of waiting.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: Why wait?

turns.speaker: MIMI
turns.text: I'm not going to wait. I'm going out -- laugh, dance --do all the things I used to do.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: And then?

turns.speaker: MIMI
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: You will die.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Please, Jacqueline.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: You know about the Palladists -- you know who they are -- what they are. I was one of them.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Good-bye, darling. I'll only be gone until three.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: Good-bye.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: If you get lonely, go down and see Mrs. Romari. I told her you were staying with me.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: I won't get lonely.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You'll be all right?

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Were you going to make a suggestion?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Yes. I was going to tell you to look into your own heart -- do you really want to find your sister?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well,then I have spoiled your dinner -- "your food won't digest, and your wine will sour."

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: You will have to make all the jokes, because I'm going to be very serious.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: At least you knew about Dr. Judd.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: And you knew he'd be here.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Yes. And now that I've shown you that I know that much, and can guess more -- will you trust me to look for Jacqueline?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I want you to look for Jacqueline.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's terribly sweet of you, Jason.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I have something even better.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I have been at the library.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But you're always at the library.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I went as a detective. I found out that Mrs. Redi reads the same books as Dr. Judd.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't think that's so revealing.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: But who is Judd, a psychiatrist. It's quite natural that he should read books on the history of old religious societies. But why should Mrs. Redi, a woman with a beauty parlor --?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: That's it. And this figure --she traced it. The book I saw at the library had been marked "perfect" by the library inspector in March. Mrs. Redi had it out in April. No one else had read it since.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm at sea, Jason.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Such a simple matter. This figure is the symbol of the Palladists.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's all clear to me now -- so clear.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I thought it would be, but just to be sure, I'll tell you that the Palladists are a society of Devil worshippers --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Devil worshippers!

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Look. I'm serious. It's a real and vary earnest society -- a dangerous society...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I can imagine.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Some time before those nice white gloves are dry you're going to go and find out a few things about Mrs. Redi.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I want you to see my room. I want you to see all of it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But it's a small room, Jason.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: It's grown big with time -- I've lived here with the Romari's for ten years -- the room's become part of me. I want you to see it  to know me better.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: My window - - through which I see the world.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's beautiful -- that searchlight - the stars --

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: It's not a searchlight  it's a sword blade cutting the blue cloak of a prince - not stars --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jason, I'm going back to Highcliffe. I came to say good-by.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I thought your coming up here to the third floor to see me -that it was your advent into my world. It turns out to be good-by. Why?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I have to go -

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: But you're happy here -- you like your work -

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: It isn't that -- you said, "have to go." What could compel you --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't make me tell you, Jason.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I thought myself your friend, Mary. Just good-bye isn't enough for a friend.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I had begun to write again -that's whet I was doing when you came in.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's because of Jacqueline  I can't go on looking for her --

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: You went to see Mrs. Redi... She told you something -- what was it?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jacqueline is a murderess she killed a man.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: And you believe that?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I have to. It was Irving August -- everything Mrs. Redi said - it fits in with what I saw - she even knew I'd seen his body on the subway.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: If it is true  there's all the more reason for you to find Jacqueline.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: And Gregory -- he loves her.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: He loves you, Mary, and you'll have to tell him.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He's Jacqueline's husband. I can't

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I can't find Gregory. I've been trying to find him.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: What's wrong, Mary?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jacqueline. Mr. Romari phoned me. She went out this afternoon with two men he'd never seen before.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: They may have been friends of hers.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I hate people who try to peddle comfort. But,Mary, you shouldn't mourn for Jacqueline. Life for her was full of the agony of a disordered mind. It's better this way.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I keep telling myself that.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Not I - I am alive, yet every hope I had is dead,  Death can be good. Death can be happy.. If I were really dying I could speak like Cyrano - "My courage like a white plume"  and all the other lovely words with which he greeted death. Then perhaps you might understand,

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I understand.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Good. We all understand each other. You, Gregory and I. We all know. There is sunlight in the streets and work to do. Both of you - you're off to work.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROMARI
turns.text: Ah, my Jason -- always laughing -- always trying to help others.  He's a good boy, Miss -- he just talks that way.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I'm a good boy, but no one listens to what I say.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROMARI
turns.text: Jason, my pet 

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Bella Romari	If I were not seated, I would embrace you in three movements like a sonata.  Ah, my wonderful one. Fly with me tonight. We will take your coffee machine and live with the gypsies.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: What are you thinking of, Bella? Can I eat dry?

turns.speaker: MRS. ROMARI
turns.text: Oh, the wine. I have forgotten the wine.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROMARI
turns.text: Why can't everyone be happy like we are -- laugh and have good times. Look at that poor little one  so sad because she can't find her sister. And that man with her - he doesn't make her laugh  he just sits and talks.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: We are happy, Mrs. Romari, because you have everything  and I am happy because I have nothing to lose.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROMARI
turns.text: But you should make her laugh, Jason. Come, make jokes for her. I'll bring your food to their table.

turns.speaker: MISS GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Jason. I really shouldn't be doing this, you know. It's against the rules.  When did you say you wanted them?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I want to see what they read so I'll know what kind of books to give my friends as presents. There's nothing nicer for a gift than a book.

turns.speaker: MISS GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: Who was the first one -- Mrs. Redi?

turns.speaker: MISS GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: And the other was Judd?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Yes, Dr. Louis Judd.

turns.speaker: MISS GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: It's here, too.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Would it be asking too much, Miss Gottschalk, for you to get me these books?

turns.speaker: MISS GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: No, not at all, Mr. Jason.

turns.speaker: MISS GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: Why, Mr. Jason. Most of these books are on the closed shelf. You have to get permission.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I wouldn't want to take them out. I just want to look at them.

turns.speaker: MISS GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: Well, since, you're over twenty one

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Where is Jacqueline Gibson?

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: What a peculiar question.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I saw you with her last week. I knew you'd be here tonight. Where is she?

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: My dear fellow, it's neither your business to ask, nor mine to tell.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: See that girl? That's Jacqueline's sister. It's because of her I ask.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: But why come to me?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Because there was another girl years ago -- a nice girl. She lived on Barrow Street. I saw her with you once - I saw her with you twice and then I never saw her again. That's why.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: She was my patient.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: What was she to you?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I don't think that you would understand if I told you.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I think I understand without your telling me. I know something of your history, Jason. I know that you haven't written for ten years.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I've lost my knack.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: After that wonderful first book - after all the adulation and the good reviews?

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: Following me to find Jacqueline?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Uhhuh.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: Well, it won't work. Love and understanding won't make a good detective out of a recalcitrant poet.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Actually I want to ask two favors of you -- one as a poet 	one as a detective.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: It sounds strange, and I'm going to be very wary.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: This is curious, Jason. Half the time you talk as if Shakespeare were not fit to tie your shoelaces; now this sudden humility.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I should like people to read what I've written.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: And this poetry  like the poetry you wrote before extols the passion and beauty of life?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: It goes beyond that. It praises the goodness of God and the greatness of all His works.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I hope it finds as much favor as your other book -- but somehow I doubt it -- the time is out of tune.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Why not let your publisher judge that?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Wait - there is that other favor.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I'd forgotten.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Tell me where Jacqueline is - we've got to find her.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: You don't expect me to do that do you?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Yes. When I tell you.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: Tell me what?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: You'll have good enough sense to tell us where she is - when you know she's a murderess. She killed a man.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: Tell me, why this sudden desire to publish  to awaken like Byron and find yourself famous.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I think it's time.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: No other reason  no woman not the little Miss Gibson?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Perhaps.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I'll do all I can to help. I'll go to my publisher tomorrow.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I'm afraid this is no time to play Cyrano, my friend. What was in your mind?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I wanted to get things clear for Jacqueline. Let her know --

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I suppose, Jason, that you'll speak for your friend --  -- and your poetry will speak for you.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Perhaps

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I don't suppose you'll ever tell her, will you?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: She is very young -- I have an old habit of failure. It would be a bad habit to bring to a marriage.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: A book of successful verse might have changed that, eh?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: It might have.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: If you like, I'll go with you to dinner.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I'd like that.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: They may have found her.  Mrs. Cortez - this morning I told her Jacqueline was no longer under my care.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Dr. Judd?

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: Yes, Miss Gibson. I've come to take you to your sister.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: Don't be so amazed. It's a very ordinary matter. I'm Jacqueline's physician... Mr. Ward told me you were in town and Jacqueline has sent me to bring you to her.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You know where she is?

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: If I didn't know where she was, could I take you to her? Get your hat and coat. We haven't much time.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: It's my cloven hoof. It trips me up sometimes.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Cloven hoof?

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: Yes. You know the devil and all his minions are marked that way.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: Yes. You could become a country wife -- fool around with petunias and pullets.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It will be fun meeting Gregory every night at the station.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Would they hurt her?

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I know the others -- Redi, Fallon, Leo, Bruns. But I would never have guessed it of you, Natalie.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: One believes - it's like any other religion...

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I'd hardly describe It that way - The worship of evil is a pretty dreadful and special thing.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: It seems right to us.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I know the theory behind the movement. If one believes in good one believes in evil. If one believes in God, one must believe in the devil. And an intelligent person can make his own choice  that's it, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: Because you are intelligent -- that's why they sent me to you --

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I think I can give you a more practical reason for your kind invitation. I know too much. I was Jacqueline's psycho-analyst.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: I always thought it was a more intimate relationship.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: Perhaps, Natalie, this is a bargain you're offering me --I am being allowed to join -- to buy safety by betraying Jacqueline -- is that it?

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: I haven't said anything of the sort.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: But you would like to know where she is?

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: Yes. There are certain punitive measures...

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I can imagine. But you did say you came to me as my friend --that you were concerned for me.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: I'm afraid you have mistaken my motive, Louis. I thought you might understand and sympathize.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I have no sympathy for either good or evil. I have only curiosity -- a professional curiosity. What unhappy people most of you are!

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: Are we?	I thought I was very gay.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: A gay lot - Redi, for instance.  I don't know what her sorrow is,	but her life's an empty one. She's had to have this to cling to. Frances Fallon, with her worship of Jacqueline, has had to follow like a sheep. And Bruns, the fanatic. And you...

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: I was a great dancer...

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: A strange collection. You're like the false god you worship... fallen angels, all of you.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: Life has betrayed us. We've found there is no heaven on earth, so we must worship evil for evil's own sake. We're not wicked. We commit no violence, unless...

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: Unless what?

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: No, you draw no secrets from me, as you drew them from Jacqueline. You are not one of us yet. You're clever, Louis, but I recognize your interest in me for what it is worth. You are only curious. You have never loved a woman who had but one arm.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: It would be a charming experience. She might only protest half as much.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: You're very flippant and perhaps wise, but not wise enough to see the truth, Louis.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: Is it about Jacqueline?

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: No. She's no longer under my care.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I don't know how to begin this, Natalie. Perhaps it's best to just plunge in. I want to join you.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: We always knew you'd come to us, Louis.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: But I'm not coming to you out of deep conviction, I'm coming to you out of loss. I no longer can believe in the power and the rightness of things that are called good.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: I never thought you did.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I've talked nonsense. I've scoffed and hooted -- but somewhere very deep down in me, I always felt that good held the balance of power.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: You're even sentimental about it. What made you change your mind?

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: This is incredible I It must be some sort of a joke.

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: I'm very, very serious.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: But you have never liked Jason. You always laughed at him - -quarreled with him --

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: And I love and admire him more than any man I ever knew. I read these poems. He's lost his talent and his was a really great gift. What I have to do today -- to bring him this rejected manuscript -will be the most disheartening thing I have ever done and the most disillusioning.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: This is the most amusing thing I have ever heard and with a bit of gossip to season it  your failure with Jacqueline. Has she returned to her husband?

turns.speaker: JUDD
turns.text: No, she's with her sister,

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But you must know someone who has seen or heard of my sister.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: I'm afraid not.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Mrs. Redi, there's one thing -with Jacqueline gone, how do you carry on the business? What do you do with the receipts? How do you sign checks--?

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: Mary, I'm amazed. Didn't Jacqueline tell you? She sold the business to me at least eight months ago. It's my business now.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I didn't know.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: Yes  and I must say I've done very well with it -- perhaps even better than Jacqueline.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: There's nothing you can think of -- old letters, anything, that might give me some hint as to where I might find Jacqueline?

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: Leave me your address, and if I find anything, I'll get in touch with you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm stopping at the Chatsworth.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: Thank you, my dear.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm afraid not.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: That's too bad.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: This is Mrs. Redi, Mary.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'll be out in a minute.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: That won't be necessary. I haven't much to say.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: If I were you, Mary -- I'd go back to school. I'd make no further attempt to find Jacqueline.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: It will make you unhappy to find Jacqueline. It would put her in danger --- great danger --

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: I can almost feel your doubt about what I'm saying, Mary.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I can't give up looking for her, Mrs. Redi, no matter what you're hinting at.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: I have no intention whatsoever of hinting. Your sister, Mary, is a murderess. She killed Irving August -- stabbed him out of fright when he discovered where she was hiding.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: I had to help get rid of the body. You saw it on the subway. And I warn you, Mary -- go back -- you don't know what you're doing, or what dreadful things you might bring about by looking for your sister. You go back to school - - go back and forget Jacqueline.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Once you'd seen my sister you'd never forget her.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROMARI
turns.text: Giacomo -- la bellisslina madonna -

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes  yes, if she made that much impression on you, I'm sure it was Jacqueline.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROMARI
turns.text: She's not been here for a long time.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But she was here?

turns.speaker: MRS. ROMARI
turns.text: Oh yes, yes. One day a beautiful car comes here. This beautiful lady in furs gets out. There is a handsome man with her, and the chauffeur  The lady rents one of our upstairs rooms. The chauffeur changes the lock on the door. Then the lady never comes back --not to live, anyhow. She came back three, four times, but always alone and just to eat.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You mean she just came here, rented the room, locked it, and left?

turns.speaker: MRS. ROMARI
turns.text: Yes -- and pays the rent every month.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Could you let me see that room? If it is hers, there might be something there to help me find my sister.

turns.speaker: MRS. LOWOOD
turns.text: Your sister - - have you heard from her lately?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, Mrs. Lowood, she doesn't write often.

turns.speaker: MRS. LOWOOD
turns.text: Have you any other relatives, Mary?

turns.speaker: MRS. LOWOOD
turns.text: That makes it all the more difficult 

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Difficult? Has anything happened to Jacqueline?

turns.speaker: MRS. LOWOOD
turns.text: We don't know, Mary. We've been unable to get in touch with your sister.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sometimes she can be quite careless. Why don't you try Mrs. Redi?

turns.speaker: MRS. LOWOOD
turns.text: I have written repeatedly to Mrs. Redi. She vouchsafes no information whatsoever.  It is six months since your tuition has been paid, Mary. Naturally, it is impossible for you to stay on here as a paying pupil.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But, Mrs. Lowood, I can't just stay here not knowing what's happened to my sister. Maybe if I went to New York -- if I saw Mrs. Redi myself --

turns.speaker: MRS. LOWOOD
turns.text: I doubt if you'll get anything out of that woman. But if  you'd like to try, I'll advance you the money to make the trip to New York. Of course, my dear, if you don't find your sister, you can always come back here.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm worry to bother you. I want to ask you about my sister.

turns.speaker: ROMARI
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I thought you might know her. She was seen here about a week ago. Her name is Jacqueline Gibson.

turns.speaker: ROMARI
turns.text: I don't know no Gibson. This is a restaurant. Many people come here.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: She's very beautiful.

turns.speaker: ROMARI
turns.text: No -- the rent in paid. The lady asked us to promise, I wouldn't open the door.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: ROMARI
turns.text: Fo come ti pare. To desiderare sempre di vedere che cosa c'era in quella stanza.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Miss Gibson, I'm tired of resting.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sh-h-h Nancy. The other children.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Is it fifteen minutes yet?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, Nancy.	You've got to sleep two more minutes.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Children, I want you to be very good and very quiet while I see Mrs. Wheeler a moment. She's going to take over this class for a while.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Why

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Because I have something very important to do.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'll be right back with Mrs. Wheeler.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: I went back through the history last night. I read about Johann Rozenquartz -- I read what he wrote --

turns.speaker: MR. BRUNS
turns.text: I can quote it fully, Mrs. Redi. "We will avoid violence. For once undertaken, violence becomes its own master and can lead to either good or evil."

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: But he also wrote --

turns.speaker: MR. BRUNS
turns.text: I can quote that too; "Those who shall go out into the market place and let their tongues speak of us, and give knowledge of our being and our deeds, whom-so-ever doeth this shall die."

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: But she told him, Frances. She told him about us.

turns.speaker: MR. BRUNS
turns.text: I know this is difficult for you. I know that you love her.

turns.speaker: MR. BRUNS
turns.text: It is a very real danger and one which forces our decision.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: What about Judd -- he knows about us.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: I have taken care of Mary. I've spoken to her. She's going back to school.

turns.speaker: MR. BRUNS
turns.text: Then it is decided. Leo and Durk and I will make our plans.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: I'm sorry to be late, Natalie.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: We haven't even begun tea yet.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: Sorry. I'm nervous. This is very trying for me.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: I know. You introduced Jacqueline to us -- but how could you tell -

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: I should have known. She had no sincerity - no real belief.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: Jacqueline, you have spoken so often of ending it all, I can't understand why this should be so difficult for you. You have only to drink a little.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: Yes, Jacqueline. You were always talking suicide - - of ending your life when you wanted to.
